questions.article: To assist with the development of new water-repellant materials for aviation and other applications, a team including both engineers and entomologists conducted a study of the water-repellant properties of cicada wings. The team explained that the ______ experts in these two disciplines resulted in a more comprehensive approach than independent efforts by experts in either discipline could have achieved.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: skepticism toward

options.name: B
options.content: exaggeration of

options.name: C
options.content: distrust among

options.name: D
options.content: collaboration between

questions.correct: collaboration between

questions.article:
The following text is adapted from John Matheus’s 1926 short story, "Mr. Bradford Teaches Sunday School." Mr. Bradford is driving through the countryside in Florida.

The moss in the towering water oaks had become enlivened with a verdant sheen of silver and hung like festoons of carnival or like funeral decorations for the mourning of the dead. The pine green was resplendent. The bald cypresses spread themselves along the watercourses while the willows wept as they always did. Mr. Bradford was conscious of this gorgeous display of nature.
questions.question: As used in the text, what does the word "display" most nearly mean?

options.name: A
options.content: Reproduction

options.name: B
options.content: Concealment

options.name: C
options.content: Pretentiousness

options.name: D
options.content: Exhibition

questions.correct: Exhibition

questions.article: Both sharks and crayfish can detect electrical fields around them, but the ______ of their sensitivities differs substantially. Whereas crayfish can detect fields emitted by household electronics, those are many times stronger than the fields created by water moving through Earth's magnetic field, which sharks are sensitive enough to detect.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: magnitude

options.name: B
options.content: firmness

options.name: C
options.content: gathering

options.name: D
options.content: orientation

questions.correct: magnitude

questions.article: New and interesting research conducted by Suleiman A. Al-Sweedan and Moath Alhaj is inspired by their observation that though studies of the effect of high altitude on blood chemistry are ______, the effect on blood chemistry of living in locations below sea level, such as the California towns of Niland and Heber, has received comparatively little notice.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: abundant

options.name: B
options.content: equivocal

options.name: C
options.content: sporadic

options.name: D
options.content: preliminary

questions.correct: abundant

questions.article:
The following text is adapted from Adib Khorram's 2018 novel Darius the Great Is Not Okay. The narrator, Darius, is a teenager visiting family in Iran. He and his friend Sohrab are at the entrance of the ruins of the ancient city of Persepolis.

“The Gate of All Nations,” Sohrab said. He gestured to the lamassus [sculptures] and pillars surrounding us. “That's the name in English.” It wasn't much of a gate anymore, since anyone of any nation could have easily stepped around it instead of walking through. But it was still amazing.

Behind the lamassu, more columns sprouted from the ground like ancient trees in a petrified forest, forty feet tall, spindly but still miraculously upright. Giant stone slabs formed the remains of what must once have been a breathtaking structure.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined portion of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: It presents an image to illustrate what one part of the ruins looks like.

options.name: B
options.content: It emphasizes that the narrator already knows a lot about the city.

options.name: C
options.content: It suggests that the narrator had expected to visit a forest.

options.name: D
options.content: It indicates the specific time in the past when the buildings became ruins.

questions.correct: It presents an image to illustrate what one part of the ruins looks like.

questions.article: Mexican architect Luis Barragan's prolific career, which spanned the 1920s to the 1980s, evolved through distinct phases. After traveling to the United States and Europe in the early 1930s and immersing himself in a broader architectural discourse, Barragan shifted his style to incorporate principles of modernism, as seen in the apartment building in Calles Lerma and Guadiana. The project's unadorned geometric forms, typical of the modernist aesthetic, contrasted with the historically inspired architecture seen in his earlier projects in Guadalajara, such as the Cristo House.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the overall structure of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: It summarizes the career of a particular architect, states how a journey influenced that architect's career, and then emphasizes how influential that architect's career has been.

options.name: B
options.content: It provides a general statement about the career of a particular architect, highlights a transition in that career, and then expounds on the ways that transition is evident in the architect's work.

options.name: C
options.content: It explains the design aesthetic of a particular architect, acknowledges the sources of those design choices, and then contrasts that aesthetic with the designs of earlier architects.

options.name: D
options.content: It presents a general claim about a particular architect's career, describes the early stages of the architect's career, and then explains a later shift in that career.

questions.correct: It provides a general statement about the career of a particular architect, highlights a transition in that career, and then expounds on the ways that transition is evident in the architect's work.

questions.article: Can field mustard plants grow on Mars? Can pea plants? You might think the answer to these questions is obviously no, but researchers in the Netherlands recently showed that the seeds of many common plant species can germinate in soil designed to simulate Martian conditions, as long as water is supplied. In fact, some species actually did better in Martian soil than in Earth soil: 30 percent of field mustard seeds sprouted when planted in simulated Martian soil, compared with 4 percent that did when planted in soil from their home planet.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: To answer long-standing questions about how Martian soil conditions can be simulated on Earth.

options.name: B
options.content: To present a surprising finding about plants grown in soil intended to be similar to Martian soil.

options.name: C
options.content: To discuss an unexpected result about the role of water in plants grown in simulated Martian soil.

options.name: D
options.content: To explain an important study of differences in the composition of Martian soil and the composition of Earth soil.

questions.correct: To present a surprising finding about plants grown in soil intended to be similar to Martian soil.

questions.article:
The following text is adapted from Jerome K. Jerome's 1889 novel Three Men in a Boat (To Say Nothing of the Dog).

We [people] are creatures of the sun. We love light and life. That is why we crowd into the towns and cities, and the country grows more and more deserted every year. In the sunlight—in the daytime, when Nature is alive and busy all around us, we like the open hill—sides and the deep woods well enough: but in the night, when our Mother Earth has gone to sleep, and left us waking, oh! the world seems so lonesome, and we get frightened, like children in a silent house. Then we sit and sob, and long for the gas-lit streets, and the sound of human voices, and the answering throb of human life.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: To address common traits that motivate many people to choose to live in urban environments

options.name: B
options.content: To indicate that people sometimes experience feelings of isolation in crowded areas

options.name: C
options.content: To illustrate the idea that most people tend to prefer hillsides in the country to certain aspects of towns and cities

options.name: D
options.content: To caution people not to be so quick to dismiss the natural beauty that can be found in rural areas

questions.correct: To address common traits that motivate many people to choose to live in urban environments

questions.article: Conservationists worldwide are working to protect ecosystems from habitat destruction and biodiversity loss, and in many cases, initiatives that rely on natural features or processes can help address such challenges. In response to a rapidly dwindling population of blueback salmon, the Quinault Indian Nation (a tribe in Washington State) partnered with the conservation organization Wild Salmon Center to restore naturally occurring logjams in the Quinault River. The logjams create shady pools where the blueback salmon can rest and spawn, thus promoting blueback population recovery.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main idea of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: A partnership between the Quinault Indian Nation and Wild Salmon Center shows the importance of collaborative approaches to preserving biodiversity.

options.name: B
options.content: As indicated by a recent project, logjams help the blueback salmon thrive and reproduce.

options.name: C
options.content: Scientists now realize that nature-based conservation methods offer better long-term solutions to environmental issues than methods that are not nature-based do.

options.name: D
options.content: Nature-based approaches can be effective ways to achieve conservation goals.

questions.correct: Nature-based approaches can be effective ways to achieve conservation goals.

questions.article: While doing research for a paper about metal exports, a student finds information about copper mining in different countries in 1995 and 2020. The student notes that Peru produced 0.38 million metric tons of copper in 1995 and ______
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses data from the table to complete the statement?

options.name: A
options.content: 1.20 million metric tons of copper in 2020.

options.name: B
options.content: 0.39 million metric tons of copper in 2020.

options.name: C
options.content: 2.15 million metric tons of copper in 2020.

options.name: D
options.content: 0.73 million metric tons of copper in 2020.

questions.correct: 2.15 million metric tons of copper in 2020.

questions.article: Puerto Rico is an island in the Caribbean Sea. Indigenous people there started raising guinea pigs about 1,700 years ago. Guinea pigs had originally been domesticated much earlier in both Colombia and Peru. So were guinea pigs brought to Puerto Rico from Colombia or from Peru? Ancient Caribbean trade routes connected Puerto Rico with Colombia but not with Peru. Therefore, guinea pigs in Puerto Rico probably came from Colombia and descended from Colombian guinea pigs.
questions.question: Which finding, if true, would most directly weaken the underlined claim?

options.name: A
options.content: Guinea pigs are common in ancient Puerto Rican art, especially in pottery.

options.name: B
options.content: Ancient guinea pigs in Puerto Rico were genetically less similar to ancient guinea pigs in Colombia than to ancient guinea pigs in Peru.

options.name: C
options.content: The guinea pig population of ancient Colombia was much larger than the guinea pig population of ancient Peru.

options.name: D
options.content: Modern breeds of guinea pigs don't look like images of guinea pigs in ancient art from Puerto Rico, Colombia, and Peru.

questions.correct: Ancient guinea pigs in Puerto Rico were genetically less similar to ancient guinea pigs in Colombia than to ancient guinea pigs in Peru.

questions.article: Unlike modern giant pandas, which are exclusive to Asia, ancient panda species were dispersed across Europe and Asia. A debate in paleontological discourse focuses on whether ancient pandas first emerged in Asia before migrating to Europe, or vice versa. A pair of European panda teeth found in Bulgaria led researchers to conclude that they likely belonged to an undiscovered species of panda that the researchers dubbed Agriarctas nikglavi. The teeth are relatively recent among European panda fossils, some of which date back to more than 10 million years ago, implying that ______.
questions.question: Which choice most logically completes the text?

options.name: A
options.content: pandas presumably originated in some part of Asia before migrating to Europe.

options.name: B
options.content: the A. nikolovi teeth suggest a later origin for pandas in Europe than was previously believed.

options.name: C
options.content: pandas likely originated in Europe since the new species was discovered in Bulgaria.

options.name: D
options.content: the A. nikolovi teeth are unlikely to assist in the resolution of the debate surrounding the origins of pandas.

questions.correct: the A. nikolovi teeth are unlikely to assist in the resolution of the debate surrounding the origins of pandas.

questions.article: Almost all works of fiction contain references to the progression of time, including the time of day when events in a story take place. In a 2020 study, Allen Kim, Charuta Pethe, and Steven Skiena claim that an observable pattern in such references reflects a shift in human behavior prompted by the spread of electric lighting in the late nineteenth century. The researchers drew this conclusion from an analysis of more than 50,000 novels spanning many centuries and cultures, using software to recognize and tally both specific time references, that is, clock phrases, such as 7 a.m. or 2:30 p.m.—and implied ones, such as mentions of meals typically associated with a particular time of day.
questions.question: Which finding from the study, if true, would most directly support the researchers' conclusion?

options.name: A
options.content: Novels published after the year 1800 include the clock phrase 10 a.m. less often than novels published before the year 1800 do.

options.name: B
options.content: Among novels published in the nineteenth century, implied time references become steadily more common than clock phrases as publication dates approach 1900.

options.name: C
options.content: The time references of noon (12 p.m.) and midnight (12 a.m.) are used with roughly the same frequency in the novels.

options.name: D
options.content: Novels published after 1880 contain significantly more references to activities occurring after 10 p.m. than do novels from earlier periods.

questions.correct: Novels published after 1880 contain significantly more references to activities occurring after 10 p.m. than do novels from earlier periods.

questions.article: As exemplified by Temiar songs about landforms and landmarks and Lakota songs about gathering mouse beans, ecological information can be transmitted in Indigenous songs, and in some instances is maintained only in this way. Kwaxsistalla Wathl’thla, a song keeper for the Kwakwaka’wakw people in Canada, collaborated with ethnobiologist Dana Lepofsky et al., sharing songs referencing terraced intertidal clam gardens the people implemented in the past to foster healthy development of a dietary staple. Drawing on archaeological evidence as well, Lepofsky et al. determined that the prevalence of the practice described in the songs corresponded with growth in clam size and abundance despite increased harvesting pressure—a finding that demonstrates that ______
questions.question: Which choice most logically completes the text?

options.name: A
options.content: representation of practical applications of ecological knowledge is the defining characteristic of the music of certain indigenous peoples.

options.name: B
options.content: the Kwakwaka’wakw people likely would not have detailed their creation of clam gardens in songs if their efforts had not produced significantly larger clams.

options.name: C
options.content: the clams harvested from intertidal terraces by Kwakwaka’wakw people in the past likely were a different species than the clams found in those areas today.

options.name: D
options.content: effective methods for the cultivation of sources of sustenance are among the ecological knowledge preserved in Indigenous songs.

questions.correct: effective methods for the cultivation of sources of sustenance are among the ecological knowledge preserved in Indigenous songs.

questions.article: A group of primate conservationists recently began a long-term study of the effects of different conservation strategies on the white-headed langur (Trachypithecus poliocephalus). The species population is currently estimated to be around 1,000. It is challenging to accurately count these primates, however, which makes it difficult to tell whether the population is increasing, decreasing, or staying stable. The study may thus ______
questions.question: Which choice most logically completes the text?

options.name: A
options.content: risk making inaccurate conclusions about the effectiveness of different conservation strategies.

options.name: B
options.content: cause other conservationists to adopt a new methodology for counting populations.

options.name: C
options.content: benefit from including species beyond the white-headed langur.

options.name: D
options.content: fail to consider less-well-known conservation approaches for the white-headed langur.

questions.correct: risk making inaccurate conclusions about the effectiveness of different conservation strategies.

questions.article: Writing in hieroglyphs, ancient Egyptians recorded measurements using units such as the sa, a unit of ______ and the khar, a unit of volume. The sa, for instance, is written as a hieroglyph that looks like a duck or goose.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: area; the shesep; a unit of length;

options.name: B
options.content: area the shesep, a unit of length

options.name: C
options.content: area; the shesep, a unit of length;

options.name: D
options.content: area, the shesep; a unit of length,

questions.correct: area; the shesep, a unit of length;

questions.article: Included in Serial Intent, a 2017 group exhibition at the Akron Art Museum in Ohio, was the work of artist Lorna Simpson, who is best known for her multimedia artworks that ______ images of African American women with text fragments. Her work is credited with expanding the horizons of conceptual photographic art, and it challenges conventional notions of race, gender, history, and memory.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: juxtapose-

options.name: B
options.content: juxtapose,

options.name: C
options.content: juxtapose:

options.name: D
options.content: juxtapose

questions.correct: juxtapose

questions.article: Contrasting a high saturation color palette against dark paper and stoneware, Atlanta-based artist Jiha Moon creates fused pieces, wherein Korean folk art, Western contemporary art, and global popular culture mix. New York's Derek Eller Gallery ______ her work in a solo exhibition that ran in early 2022.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: features

options.name: B
options.content: has been featured

options.name: C
options.content: featured

options.name: D
options.content: will feature

questions.correct: featured

questions.article: While the greater adjutant can be found in places like the Inner Gulf of Thailand and the Chhep Wildlife Sanctuary in Cambodia, more than 80 percent of this endangered stork species is found in Assam, India. There, wildlife biologist Dr. Purnima Devi Barman is on the front lines of conservation efforts that—through community involvement and scientific ______ aim to bring adjutants back from near extinction.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: study,

options.name: B
options.content: study—

options.name: C
options.content: study:

options.name: D
options.content: study

questions.correct: study—

questions.article: The human shoulder contains the infraspinatus, a skeletal muscle that is attached to the ______ this muscle plays a role in rotating the upper arm.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: scapula,

options.name: B
options.content: scapula;

options.name: C
options.content: scapula

options.name: D
options.content: scapula that

questions.correct: scapula;

questions.article: The unconventional literary philosophy with which Fernando Pessoa approached his writing is manifested in the Portuguese poet's “heteronyms,” his term for the dozens of fictional personas in whose voices he authored many of his ______ among these personas was Ricardo Reis, author of classical odes in a Horatian style.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: works: and

options.name: B
options.content: works;

options.name: C
options.content: works and

options.name: D
options.content: works,

questions.correct: works;

questions.article: William Shakespeare likely arrived in London as early as 1585, at the age of 21, to pursue a career in the theater. Little is known of his early years there, but by 1593 he was becoming known for plays such as Richard III. ______ in 1599, he would delight audiences with Much Ado About Nothing, considered by some to be one of his greatest works.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: In other words,

options.name: B
options.content: Conversely,

options.name: C
options.content: Thus,

options.name: D
options.content: Later,

questions.correct: Later,

questions.article: Soil polluted with cadmium (a heavy metal) is harmful to many plants and animals, but the plant species Elodea canadensis, or Canadian waterweed, not only thrives in such conditions but also helps remediate them. As a metal hyperaccumulator, Elodea canadensis absorbs a large amount of cadmium and stores it safely in its roots and shoots; ______ cadmium concentrations in the soil decrease.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: specifically,

options.name: B
options.content: nevertheless,

options.name: C
options.content: in addition,

options.name: D
options.content: accordingly,

questions.correct: accordingly,

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • A supercontinent is a single landmass made up of most or all of Earth's continents.
  • Over time, continents merge together to form supercontinents, which then break apart.
  • This process is believed to take hundreds of millions of years and is known as the supercontinent cycle.
  • Ur and Columbia were supercontinents.
  • Ur formed about 3.1 billion years ago.
  • Columbia formed about 1.8 billion years ago.
questions.question: The student wants to specify when Ur formed. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: Ur was a supercontinent, a single landmass made up of most or all of Earth’s continents.

options.name: B
options.content: The supercontinent Ur formed about 3.1 billion years ago.

options.name: C
options.content: Long ago, the Earth was home to supercontinents like Ur and Columbia.

options.name: D
options.content: Over hundreds of millions of years, the supercontinent cycle results in supercontinents forming and breaking apart.

questions.correct: The supercontinent Ur formed about 3.1 billion years ago.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Ixmiquilpan is a municipality in the state of Hidalgo, Mexico.
  • Municipalities are governmental regions responsible for providing many public services to their residents.
  • One service they provide is water treatment.
  • Ixmiquilpan’s population was 98,654 in 2020.
  • Hidalgo is divided into 84 municipalities.
questions.question: The student wants to provide an example of a public service that Ixmiquilpan is responsible for. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: Ixmiquilpan is one of 84 municipalities in Hidalgo providing public services to their communities.

options.name: B
options.content: Ixmiquilpan—a governmental region in the state of Hidalgo, Mexico—provides public services to its residents.

options.name: C
options.content: As a municipality, Ixmiquilpan is responsible for providing water treatment to its residents.

options.name: D
options.content: In 2020, the municipality of Ixmiquilpan had a population of 98,654.

questions.correct: As a municipality, Ixmiquilpan is responsible for providing water treatment to its residents.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Oak Tree House is an Ancestral Puebloan dwelling site located in southwestern Colorado.
  • It was built under a rock overhang and inhabited from approximately 1180—1210 CE.
  • The overhanging rock ledges offered protection from heavy rain and snow.
  • Yucca House is an Ancestral Puebloan dwelling site located in southwestern Colorado.
  • It was built on relatively flat terrain and inhabited from approximately 1080—1275 CE.
  • This level surface allowed for the construction of large terraced buildings.
questions.question: The student wants to explain an advantage of the Oak Tree House dwelling site. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: The location of Oak Tree House, an Ancestral Puebloan dwelling site in southwestern Colorado, provided an advantage to its inhabitants.

options.name: B
options.content: Located in southwestern Colorado, Oak Tree House is an Ancestral Puebloan dwelling site that was inhabited from approximately 1180—1210 CE.

options.name: C
options.content: The relatively flat terrain on which Oak Tree House was built allowed for the construction of large terraced buildings.

options.name: D
options.content: Since it was built under a rock overhang, Oak Tree House was naturally protected from heavy rain and snow.

questions.correct: Since it was built under a rock overhang, Oak Tree House was naturally protected from heavy rain and snow.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • In a 2010 study, researchers Katrin Heer, Larissa Albrecht, and Elisabeth K.V. Kalko wanted to explore the effects of ingestion by bats on the germination of Ficus obtusifolia seeds in Panama.
  • The team of researchers tested 120 Ficus obtusifolia seeds that had been ingested by Jamaican fruit bats.
  • Of these, 111 seeds (93%) germinated.
  • As a control, K. Heer et al. tested 120 Ficus obtusifolia seeds that had not been ingested by Jamaican fruit bats.
  • Of these, 116 seeds (97%) germinated.
questions.question: The student wants to describe the study's research methodology. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: In the study, a lower percentage of Ficus obtusifolia seeds ingested by bats germinated than those that had not been ingested by bats.

options.name: B
options.content: The team of researchers tested the germination of 120 Ficus obtusifolia seeds that had been ingested by Jamaican fruit bats and 120 Ficus obtusifolia seeds that had not been ingested.

options.name: C
options.content: K. Heer et al. wanted to explore the effects of Jamaican fruit bats ingestion on Ficus obtusifolia seed germination.

options.name: D
options.content: Research by K. Heer et al. revealed that 111 of 120 (that is, 93%) of the Ficus obtusifolia seeds that had been ingested by Jamaican fruit bats germinated.

questions.correct: The team of researchers tested the germination of 120 Ficus obtusifolia seeds that had been ingested by Jamaican fruit bats and 120 Ficus obtusifolia seeds that had not been ingested.
